page.title: 04CADSON BURY
page.content: This striking hill of resistant chert is the site of an{Iron Age hill {fort,}set up by peoples from Europe in the 3rd and 4th centuries B.C. The steep sides of up to 30 degrees and flat top made an ideal site for{defence}in troubled times. However, it is thought that there was no permanent settlement on the hill top: the people lived close to the R. Lynher for{water supply,}and moved up to Cadson Bury when danger threatened. The hill fort is classed as a {Defensive Earthworks with Single {Banks,}and the remains of the earthworks can still be clearly seen on the summit. Most obvious is the {ditch}of up to 4m depth which rings the hill for over 500m. Cadson Bury, being of historical interest, is now{National Trust property.
